Potassium Management: Potassium addition is tailored based on serum potassium levels. When serum potassium levels are within a normal range, add approximately 40 milliequivalents of potassium chloride (KCL) per liter of IV fluid administered. This ensures adequate potassium levels to prevent hypokalemia.

 

Monitoring

 

  • If serum potassium is below 3.3, administer IV potassium chloride (KCL) before insulin to prevent hypokalemia-induced arrhythmias.
  • If serum potassium is between 3.3 and 5.2, administer insulin and KCL together.
  • If serum potassium exceeds 5.3 & above, administer insulin without KCL and monitor serum potassium closely.

 

Treatment Goals and Precautions:

 

  • Aim for a target CBG of 200 to 300 mg/dL to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • The common causes of death in patients with DKA, particularly during the treatment phase – 
    • Cerebral edema (MC) may occur due to a rapid decrease in blood glucose levels, which can lead to an osmotic shift. This shift causes fluids to move from the extracellular fluid (ECF) to the intracellular fluid (ICF), resulting in swelling of the brain tissue.
    • 2nd MC cause is Potassium Disorder esp. Hypokalemia, this can result in ventricular arrythmias.
    • Other causes include ARDS, patients can initially develop acute kidney injury (pre-renal), later if severe, leads to ATN (Acute tubular necrosis) due to hypoperfusion of kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is not suitable for acute management due to its prolonged action and delayed onset, making it inappropriate for rapid correction of hyperglycemia and ketonemia.

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin: While regular insulin is appropriate, the subcutaneous route is less effective in severe DKA where IV administration allows for better control and titration.

 

Option C. Intravenous insulin I.V. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is never administered IV due to the risk of prolonged hypoglycemia and lack of titratability. It is also not designed for acute management settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the initial steps involve aggressive IV fluid resuscitation followed by IV regular insulin to rapidly lower blood glucose and resolve ketosis.

questions.text: In which age group is Paget's disease of the breast not observed? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Childhood 

 

Explanation:

 

Paget's disease of the breast is a rare manifestation of breast cancer characterized by unilateral nipple eczema, nipple discharge, and scaly crust. It represents the extension of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) into the nipple epidermis without basement membrane invasion. Since breast cancer is primarily a disease of older women with 75% occurring in those over 50 years of age, Paget's disease follows this pattern and is not observed in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adolescent: While uncommon, breast cancer can occur in adolescents, making Paget's disease possible though rare in this age group.

 

Option C. Adult: Paget's disease is commonly observed in adults, as this is when breast cancer incidence rises significantly.

 

Option D. Elderly: The elderly population has the highest incidence of breast cancer, making Paget's disease relatively more common in this age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paget's disease of the breast represents underlying ductal carcinoma extending into the nipple epidermis with characteristic clinical findings of unilateral nipple eczema and discharge. It is predominantly HER2-positive (>80-90%) and HR-negative, and follows the age distribution pattern of breast cancer, being absent in childhood.

questions.text: Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral Medullary syndrome.

 

LATERAL MEDULLARY SYNDROME:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Weber is a medial midbrain syndrome caused by occlusion of PCA branches.

 

Option C: Medial medullary syndrome (aka Dejerine syndrome) supplied by vertebral/spinal artery.

 

Option D: Millard-Gubler is a lateral pontine syndrome involving peripheral LMN of 7th and 6th nerve (NOT NUCLEUS!) supplied by AICA.

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

 

In the case of a patient presenting with palpitations, narrow complex tachycardia, and hypotension (BP 70/40 mm Hg), the patient is considered hemodynamically unstable. The appropriate management for an unstable patient with a pulse is synchronized DC cardioversion. This intervention is critical to restore normal rhythm promptly and prevent deterioration.

 

Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock that is timed with the QRS complex, preventing the shock from falling on the T wave, which could induce ventricular fibrillation. This is the standard treatment for unstable supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Adenosine (6mg): IV Adenosine is used for the treatment of stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not appropriate for an unstable patient due to its transient effect and the need for rapid intervention in unstable conditions.

 

Option C. Carotid Sinus Massage: Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to manage stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not recommended for unstable patients because it may not be effective quickly enough to stabilize the patient.

 

Option D. IV Amiodarone: IV Amiodarone is typically used for stable wide complex tachycardia, especially monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is not the first-line treatment for unstable narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: The Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing which of the following conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute severe ulcerative colitis

 

The Truelove and Witt criteria are specifically used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis. These criteria help classify the disease into mild, moderate, or severe categories.


Another set of criteria called the Travis criteria is used to assess treatment response and predict the risk of progression to surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalitis: Incorrect because encephalitis has its own specific diagnostic criteria and severity assessment tools that focus on neurological symptoms and findings.

 

Option C. ARDS: Incorrect because ARDS is diagnosed and classified using the Berlin criteria (2012), which primarily use the P/F ratio (PaO2/FiO2) with a PEEP of at least 5 cm H2O.

 

Option D. Acute pancreatitis: Incorrect because acute pancreatitis has scoring systems for severity assessment, such as Ranson's criteria or the APACHE II score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis.

 

Truelove and Witt's Criteria for Severity of Ulcerative Colitis

questions.text: If all extraocular muscles are paralysed, where would you suspect the lesion? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brainstem

 

The brainstem houses the nuclei of the cranial nerves responsible for eye movements. Paralysis of all extraocular muscles suggests a lesion affecting these nuclei or their associated pathways within the brainstem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal eye field: Lesions here cause ipsilateral gaze deviations and saccadic eye movement disorders, not complete paralysis of extraocular muscles.

 

Option B. Cerebral surface: Cerebral lesions usually do not cause paralysis of all extraocular muscles but may affect ipsilateral voluntary eye movements.

 

Option D. Spinal cord: The spinal cord does not control the extraocular muscles; it is involved in motor and sensory pathways for the limbs and trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paralysis of all extraocular muscles typically indicates a brainstem lesion affecting cranial nerve nuclei.

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting. On examination, his HR is 58 and BP is 90/60 mm of Hg. ECG was done and it shows the following finding. Cardiac biomarkers showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior wall MI

 

The symptoms of severe chest pain, pain radiating to the left arm, profuse sweating, nausea, and vomiting, combined with hypotension (BP 90/60 mmHg) and bradycardia (HR - 58), strongly suggest an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Elevated troponin levels confirm myocardial injury.

 

ECG findings – ST elevation in lead II, III & aVf – inferior wall MI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior wall MI: Typically presents with tachycardia rather than bradycardia and different ECG findings.

 

ECG - ST elevation in V1 to V4 – anterior wall MI

 

Option C. Posterior wall MI: Less common and often associated with ST depression in V1-V3 rather than the symptoms described.

 

ECG - ST elevation in V7, V8 & V9 and characteristic pattern of tall R wave, ST depression in V1-V2 and an upright T wave – Posterior wall MI

 

Option D. Pericarditis: Presents with pleuritic type of chest pain that is relieved by leaning forward and may have a pericardial friction rub on auscultation, not necessarily accompanied by the severe hemodynamic instability described here.

 

ECG finding – Global ST elevation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior wall MI is characterized by chest pain, bradycardia, hypotension, and elevated troponin levels.

 

MC affected right coronary artery.
